Should i complete whole specialization  And how should I do practice on leetcode and interviewbit..... Please can you guide me  I want to do preparation in quarantine from starting

@yagamilight1690   Completing whole specialization is not needed, just cover up till graph and practice (easy + medium) on leetcode, after solving around 400-500 question then start solving fresh in InterviewBit.  Note: leetcode discussion section is awesome. I love that. Actually, I learnt alot there. Start exploring you'd enjoy for sure.
One more thing, revise as much as possible. Because we all know, how we forget things very quickly. I solved same question atleast 5 times.  For revision: you can only solve again in InterviewBit
@MithleshKumar-iz1dz  So first i will do course till graph then practice or alongside course And it will enough or Competitive programming needed for product bases companies

@yagamilight1690  I did after completing the course, but it would be good if you practice alongside (only 10-15 required in beginning for each topic just to understand topic well). Otherwise you would start forgetting that I was having.

I’ve been through all this struggle in finding the right resources to learn DS&A and prepare for interviews! This is my two cents: The mycodeschool channel is good, short, and straight to the points without losing much detail. The MIT course is way too long and academic but it is good if you have the time, which I didn’t so I skipped it. The Algorithm book by Prof. Segdewick is a book for the second course in CS, which focuses mostly on the fundamental yet important data structures, how they are implement in Java, as well as some associated algorithmic problems. The book doesn’t mention Algorithm design techniques (again, mostly on data structures and not design techniques). Then, the Algorithm Design Manual by Prof. Skiena is a book for a course followed by the Data Structure course (usually named "Design and Analysis of Algorithms"). This book briefly talks about data structures and doesn’t talk about how they are implemented. It assumes readers know the basics of data structures. It focuses on Algorithm design techniques such as divide-and-conquer, dynamic programming, etc. The following is my recommended learning path if you have over 8 months and not much background in CS: Pick a language and learn the basics of it (Java), watch the mycodeschool playlist on Data Structures, read the “Algorithm” textbook by Prof. Sedgewick alongside with his two Coursera courses (which use his textbook), read Prof. Skiena’s “The Algorithm Design Manual” alongside with the Stanford algorithm course on Coursera (optional in my opinion, because it uses the CLRS textbook and talks about a lot of math. Watch it if you want to pursue a CS master/phd and and pursue the academic route instead of industry). Then buy the CtCi or Elements of Programming Interviews book AND use Leetcode to practice solving algorithmic problems for interviews. Finally, buy the CLRS/Knuth’s classic books as a lifetime reference. All these books work well TOGETHER and serve different purposes! If you are short on time AND have some background in CS (preferably Data Structures, OOD, and programming basics), then I'd recommend skipping Sedgewick's Algorithm book and start from Skiena's book on design techniques and then CiTi/EPI + LeetCode + Mock interviews. Hope this help save some of your precious brain cells. You are welcome.

For videos, I think the Stanford's Algorithms course on Cousera by Tim Roughgarden is solid, and there is a 24 part online lecture by Robert Sedgewick that is also worth watching. Still, Cracking the Coding Interview and Elements of Programming Interviews are way more practical if taking a technical interview with the big four. Of course, if you can finish all 800+ problems on LeetCode within several months, finding a job should be a cake. PS: The Algorithm Design Manual is the suggested Algorithms book in Google's Interview Preparation Email. I know because I interviewed with Google before. That said, I don't think you can go wrong with any popular Algorithms book. Just go through with one and internalize the concepts.
Introduction to algorithms (clrs)
Cracking the coding interview

The red-cover "Algorithm Design" by Skiena has gotten a lot of bad reviews on Amazon (1 Star), such as 'the coding examples don't work' and that this is a good "Theory" book, but its "Design in C" is flawed.
